node.text:
Lyuba's school was bombed beyond recognition in eastern Ukraine. This is what it looks like now.

Hostilities across the world have devastated young people's access to education, and COVID-19 has made things even worse.

Whether living through peace or conflict, children's right to learn must be protected. 

#NotATarget

node.text:
Lyuba's school was bombed beyond recognition in eastern Ukraine. This is what it looks like now.

Hostilities across the world have devastated young people's access to education, and COVID-19 has made things even worse.

Whether living through peace or conflict, children's right to learn must be protected. 

#NotATarget

The public water system in Lebanon is about to collapse.

#worldwaterweek

node.text:
“We have to act now.”

María in Mexico sees how climate change is transforming the world and endangering the most vulnerable - and she’s taking action. #FridaysforFuture

node.title: Advocating for climate justice in Mexico

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 10, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing, outdoors and text that says '"Our school had already been damaged by the hurricane in 2016. Now the earthquake destroyed it." Richenaelle, 5 ©UNICEF/3N0511433/Crickx unicef for every child'.

node.text:
Over 100,000 children won't go to school this September because of the devastation caused by Haiti's recent earthquake.

UNICEF, along with the Ministry of Education, is working against the clock to install temporary learning spaces so children can continue their education and receive psychosocial support.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"To have a better future, we all need to learn to take care of our environment." Simon, 17, Haiti'.
Photo by UNICEF on September 09, 2021. May be an illustration of 1 person and text that says 'COME ME TO NEW NORMAL LIFE School Reran'.

node.text:
“I’m excited to go back to school after the long closure due to COVID-19. Maintaining all safety measures, we will again enjoy playing with and talking to friends.”

After over a year of waiting, 11-year-old Rihan from Bangladesh is happy to hear that schools will finally be reopening. What have you been looking forward to most about being back in the classroom?

#ReopenSchools © UNICEF Bangladesh

node.text:
Lyuba's school was bombed beyond recognition in eastern Ukraine. This is what it looks like now.

Hostilities across the world have devastated young people's access to education, and COVID-19 has made things even worse.

Whether living through peace or conflict, children's right to learn must be protected. 

#NotATarget

node.text: Enough. Attacks on students, teachers and places of education must stop. #NotATarget

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 08, 2021. May be an image of child and headscarf.

node.text:
"It was terrible. Some girls were screaming, running to the school gate. We lost so many students."

In May 2021, 13-year-old Lameah and her sister survived a senseless attack on their school in Kabul, Afghanistan. Many of their much loved friends and teachers did not. That day, 85 people were killed and over 200 were injured.

On International Day to Protect Education from Attack, our message is clear: Schools are #NotATarget.

© UNICEF/UN0514369/

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 08, 2021. May be a closeup of 1 person, long hair and indoor.

node.text:
“COVID-19 has left a very profound change in the way I live,” says 14-year-old Anna from Italy. “It did not help me to find a way to express emotions. I now fear physical contact, and I’m conscious that my reactions to the world have very much changed.”  

The pandemic has upended mental and emotional health worldwide. Explore the experiences of young people and help us reimagine a better future for every child. 👉 https://uni.cf/generation-covid-italy

@magnumphotos 

© UNICEF/UN0483565/Majoli/Magnum Photos

node.text:
"School was supposed to open in September but the earthquake crushed everything."

10-year-old Betrand had already missed months of school because of COVID-19 and insecurity in Haiti. Now, an earthquake has pushed back learning for over 100,000 children.

This latest disaster must not define their futures. With partners, UNICEF is reaching children with mental health support, and working to get students back into the classroom.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 07, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
“I started working last year when my school closed due to the COVID-19 lockdown," says 9-year-old Valentinne from Bolivia as she stands in front of her school with a blank notebook. The pandemic has turned her life upside down, forcing her to drop out. Without adequate digital devices and internet access at home, she was unable to continue her studies remotely. She now sells handkerchiefs on the streets. 
 
We need to get students back in classrooms as soon as possible. The longer we wait, the less likely they are to return and the higher the risk of child labour, marriage, early pregnancy, violence and abuse. As governments work to reopen schools, keeping children learning and ensuring no one falls behind is critical.
 
© UNICEF/UN0499921/UN0499911/UN0499905/Czajkowskito

node.text:
Nyalang and her little sister were taken from their home in broad daylight.

Abductions of women and children are commonplace in South Sudan. Girls are vulnerable to rape and sexual assault, while boys are recruited as soliders.

“After we were abducted, we walked for more than 14 days, through the bushes," says Nyalang. "We barely had anything to eat or to drink. Once I asked for water for my little sister. I was beaten.”

Thankfully, UNICEF and partners were able to help secure Nyalang’s release, and reunited her with her family. Yet a year on, it has been a long and painful road for Nyalak and her sister.

We cannot sit idly by and watch gross atrocities continue. Join us in calling for children living in conflict to be protected now.

#NotATarget

© UNICEF/UN0475230

node.text:
These children in Herat are some of the 300,000 who've fled their homes due to conflict in Afghanistan. 

UNICEF and partners continue to provide safe places for boys and girls to play, learn and receive mental health support across the country. 

Following decades of conflict, natural disasters, and most recently, the COVID-19 pandemic, children and their families need protection more than ever. Find out more about UNICEF's response by tapping the link in our bio.
